intro: Balanites angolensis subsp. welwitschii, commonly known as the wild date tree, is a shrub or small tree native to arid and semi-arid regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the family Bombacaceae and is characterized by its thick, waxy leaves that help reduce water loss in dry environments. The plant produces yellow flowers followed by woody capsules containing edible, sweet seeds often referred to as "wild dates." Its roots can penetrate deep into the soil to access groundwater, making it highly drought-tolerant. The plant is also valued for its medicinal properties and is used in traditional medicine for various ailments.
